title: Should a lawyer use 'Esq.' after their name? - Quora

response.answer_text: For the U.S. legal profession, it’s ultimately nothing more than historical habits and convention. However, no state law has stipulated that “esquire” (“Esq.”) is reserved for any profession or class. Nonetheless, some states have some kind of written or unwritten rule to protect the use of the term “esquire” to denote legal licensure — so the net effect is that anyone using “Esq.” after the name is tantamount to unauthorised practice of law. I don’t think it’s hard to fathom how “Esq.” got adopted by the legal profession as a professionalised courtesy title. American society isn’t replete with formal titles like UK society historically has with various peerage, non-peerage and other official titles. When official titles do come up in American society, they’re rather functional and nondescript. UK professional titles tend to sound just a little ‘grander’:— Head of the U.S. judiciary — Chief Justice of the United StatesHead of the English judiciary — Lord Chief Justice of England and WalesHead of the Scottish judiciary — Lord President of the Court of Session and Lord Justice-GeneralThe American legal habit of using “Esq.” to mean a lawyer probably started with the U.S. diplomatic service — because “esquire” in full is/was typically used as a complimentary title for a Foreign Service commissioned officer. That American diplomatic usage probably came from general British secretarial practice. In the UK today, using “Esq.” has no precise and no special significance overall — it’s just a general courtesy title for any MAN (not woman) in formal or professional correspondence. In the UK, it has no specific connection to the legal profession.

I use Esq (or Esquire) when it is appropriate. My email signature in both of my professional email addresses uses Esquire. In my personal email account, I do not use Esquire. If I write a letter when I am acting as an attorney, I tend to use Esquire.  I do this so people know they are communicating with an attorney. I feel it is important that I properly communicate my role in whatever I am handling, and using Esquire is a quick way of doing so. I don't want people to feel as if I sought to fool them. If whatever I am writing is not related to a legal issue, I don't generally use Esquire. I don't use Esquire (or the fact that I am a lawyer) in my day-to-day life. By that I mean, I don't sign personal correspondence with Jennifer Ellis, Esquire. If people want to refer to me as such, they may feel free. But it is not necessary and I don't care one way or the other.
